cards.title: Palmyra / Amateur footage purports to show crowd burning Assad's portrait
cards.rawTitle: Amateur footage purports to show crowd burning Assad's portrait

item.title: Amateur footage purports to show crowd burning Bashar al-Assad portrait in Palmyra
item.trailText: Amateur video purports to show people burning a portrait of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad in Palmyra after the historic city fell under the control of Isis
item.standFirst: Amateur video purports to show people burning a portrait of Syrian president Bashar al-Assad in Palmyra after the historic city fell under the control of Isis. The description on the video posted to social media claims that it was filmed near the Tadmor Palmyra prison. Palmyra is home to some of the most beautiful and well-preserved ruins of antiquity

cards.title: Beachy keen / Riviera style from the past 100 years
cards.rawTitle: Riviera style from the past 100 years

item.title: Riviera Style from the past 100 years
item.trailText: A new exhibition celebrating swimwear from the past 100 years opens at the Fashion and Textile Museum in London on Friday. From swimming costumes at the English seaside to bikinis on the Côte d’Azur, be inspired this summer
item.standFirst: A new exhibition celebrating swimwear from the past 100 years opens at the Fashion and Textile Museum in London on Friday. From swimming costumes at the English seaside to bikinis on the Côte d’Azur, be inspired this summer

cards.title: You can teach young dogs new, acrobatic tricks – video
cards.rawTitle: You can teach young dogs new, acrobatic tricks

item.title: You can teach young dogs new, acrobatic tricks
item.trailText: After only 20 months' training, two energetic border collies called Holly and Ace perform acrobatic tricks at their home in Sydney
item.standFirst: After only 20 months' training, two energetic border collies called Holly and Ace perform acrobatic tricks at their home in Sydney. As soon as he adopted them, Dai Aoki began teaching nine-month-old Holly and six-month-old Ace tricks such as balancing on two paws on their owner's leg and pushing one another in a pram

stillImage.caption: Acrobat dogs perform with their owner Dai Aoki in Sydney. 21 May 2015 Photograph: Dai Aoki/Reuters Photograph: Dai Aoki/Reuters

cards.title: Rohingya migrants / Indonesian fishermen to the rescue

item.title: Indonesian fishermen rescue Rohingya migrants
item.trailText: Several hundred migrants from Myanmar and Bangladesh arrive in in Indonesia's northwestern Aceh province on Wednesday after being helped to land by local fishermen
item.standFirst: Several hundred migrants from Myanmar and Bangladesh arrive in in Indonesia's northwestern Aceh province on Wednesday after being helped to land by local fishermen. The latest group brought to shore adds to the over 3,000 who have landed in Indonesia and Malaysia this month, after weeks of drifting in the Andaman Sea with little food or water

cards.title: New York / Bear tranquilized after 11-hour standoff in tree
cards.rawTitle: Bear tranquilized after 11-hour standoff in tree

item.title: Bear tranquilized in New York after 11-hour standoff in tree
item.trailText: Officials tranquilized a black bear about 12 miles outside midtown Manhattan after it roamed a populated Yonkers neighborhood for three days
item.standFirst: Officials tranquilized a black bear about 12 miles outside midtown Manhattan after it roamed a populated Yonkers neighborhood for three days. It is due to be released on state-owned land farther upstate. Officials are warning residents to properly secure their trash and leave nothing to tempt bears in the future

stillImage.caption: Officials tranquilize a black bear in New York after they say it roamed a populated Yonkers neighborhood for three days Photograph: Reuters Photograph: Reuters

cards.title: My best shot / A mother breastfeeding in Afghanistan

item.title: Alixandra Fazzina’s best photograph: a mother breastfeeding in Afghanistan
item.trailText: ‘Many women die giving birth in Badakhshan. The nearest hospital is three days away by donkey’
item.standFirst: ‘Many women die giving birth in Badakhshan. The nearest hospital is three days away by donkey’
item.body:
This image was taken in Badakhshan, a province in north-east Afghanistan with the highest rate of maternal mortality in the world. There are 6,500 deaths for every 100,000 births. Women marry very young, and it’s so remote that getting professional healthcare is almost impossible – it takes two or three days on a donkey to reach the nearest hospital. I went there in 2008 to shoot a project for Oxfam and found a lot of orphans whose mothers had died while having them.

Women in Badakhshan rely on their mothers-in-law or “birth attendants” in the community to help them through pregnancy and birth. I visited one attendant at her home, where she was weaving carpets, and I drank tea with her family and neighbours. Her name was Hanifa and her daughter Siamoy was sitting there breastfeeding in this beautiful light. My pictures often start with a conversation or a cup of tea, rather than the lens: I don’t believe I have the automatic right to take anybody’s photograph, and I hate the idea of stealing a shot. So, only after a while did I pick up my camera.

I took about 10 frames of Siamoy. People say this image looks religious, kind of iconic, like a Madonna and child, but I’ve never seen that. I think it’s something more simple: there is a beauty to Siamoy, a power and serenity showing something dignified about motherhood.

At the time, Oxfam wouldn’t publish it because they thought it would cause offence. NGOs have strict ethical guidelines on taking pictures, which I absolutely agree with for the most part, but this I found extraordinary. The breast has become so sexualised, many don’t even see it as part of motherhood. You can see the top of Siamoy’s breast, but that is no more than you could see in the UK walking down the street.

Related: Caught in conflict: women in Pakistan

I shot lots of beautiful photos on this trip, so I didn’t think it was a very significant picture – until I sent it to Time magazine. They selected it as one of their top 10 photographs of 2008, which generated a lot more awareness about maternal mortality than perhaps an NGO campaign could. It has elicited quite a response. People have even painted it.

I’ve always loved working in Afghanistan. It is harsh but beautiful, with its mountain air and rugged landscapes. But I’ve never been back to Badakhshan. I wanted to, but in 2010 the Taliban began to attack NGO workers in the region. It is now almost no-go.

CV

Born: London, 1974.

Studied: Fine arts at University of West England, Bristol.

Influences: “My experience and my environment.”

High point: “I won the UNHCR Nansen Refugee award in 2010. I am the only journalist to ever win it.”

Low point: “I’ve been under fire a lot, targeted by the Taliban, and held as a political prisoner by Charles Taylor’s militia in Liberia.”

Top tip: “It’s not just about getting a good picture. Seek out interesting storylines.”

cards.title: Four mile oil slick / The ruptured pipeline spill off the Californian coast
cards.rawTitle: The ruptured pipeline spill off the Californian coast

item.title: Ruptured pipeline on California coast spills oil into ocean
item.trailText: An oil slick four miles wide is created in Santa Barbara after 21,000 gallons of oil spills into the Pacific Ocean. The US coast guard, county emergency officials and state parks officials were cleaning up the spill
item.standFirst: An oil slick four miles wide is created in Santa Barbara after 21,000 gallons of oil spills into the Pacific Ocean. The US coast guard, county emergency officials and state parks officials were cleaning up the spill on Wednesday

displayImages.caption: Officials inspect the oil-covered beach after about 21,000 gallons spilled from the pipeline near Refugio State Beach, spreading over about four miles of beach within hours Photograph: David McNew/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Officials inspect the oil-covered beach after about 21,000 gallons spilled from the pipeline near Refugio State Beach, spreading over about four miles of beach within hours.
